CHN and RUS conduct joint exercises on average about once every 9 months, but the sample of only two previous full scale exercises is small.  The latest exercise was conducted in September 2020 was a land exercise.  The last naval exercise was in December 2019. The window of 01 March seems a bit tight (6 months), especially as RUS struggles to gain control of COVID.  I would expect an exercise some time in the late summer when weather is more favorable for naval exercises in general and once both RUS and CHN have gotten COVID behind them. I asked a question about whether observer status counts for the purposes of a joint exercise.  If I get a reply, this would impact my estimate.

China & Russia have conducted joint naval exercises eight times since 2012.  Most recent exercises include:
- 2019 with Iran in the Indian Ocean and Gulf of Oman - https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-military-russia-china/russia-china-iran-start-joint-naval-drills-in-indian-ocean-idUSKBN1YV0IB.
- 2017 in the Sea of Japan - https://www.russiamatters.org/blog/growing-scope-russian-chinese-naval-exercises-points-closer-ties. 
- 2017 in the Baltic Sea - https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/25/world/europe/china-russia-baltic-navy-exercises.html.  
- 2016  in the South China Sea.
- 2015 in Med - https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-russia-military/china-russia-to-hold-first-joint-mediterranean-naval-drills-in-may-idUSKBN0NL16F20150430 Since they have not conducted joint exercises since December 2019, it's likely that they would plan one for 2021, both because their past exercise schedule usually includes one joint naval exercise per year and because it could be an effective show of force for the new Biden administration.  However, Russia and China may be more cautious due to COVID, so I lowered my forecast slightly.

According to https://www.swp-berlin.org/fileadmin/contents/products/comments/2019C26_pau.pdf, China and Russia have conducted 10 bilateral naval exercises since 2012 or 1.1 per year.  However the scope of this question allows for multilateral exercises in which they both participate.  Thus, I'll use a 1.5 exercise per year base rate.  With 12 weeks remaining in the window, the base rate is 34%.  That said, none of the bilateral exercises have occurred between Dec and Mar(though last year's tri-lateral exercise with Iran took place in Dec) and there is currently no open source reporting I can find that indicates an impending naval exercise or planning thereof.  Thus, I'm downgrading the 34% to 25% and will monitor the news for any forthcoming naval exercises.

RU & CH conduct a major bilateral or multilateral joint exercise “almost yearly” beginning in 2005: Peace Mission 2005, Peace Mission 2010, Naval Interaction 2012, Peace Mission 2012, Naval Interaction 2013, Peace Mission 2013, Naval Interaction 2014, Peace Mission 2014. Since 2012, Ch & Ru have held annual naval exercises, with CH reporting they were to be normalized and institutionalized. https://apps.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a616312.pdf. None of these annual naval bilats have occurred before late April of the calendar year:
Maritime Cooperation 2012 Apr 22-27 in Yellow Sea

Realist balance-of-power considerations versus institutional and regional relationship-building considerations provide different potential outcomes, all of which would require an in-depth understanding of Chinese and Russian decision-making. In addition to the linked exercises, Russia and China have collaborated in multilateral (not bilateral) land exercises as recently as September 2020 (1) and conducted naval drills alongside Iran in 2019(2).  
Factors related to the 'why' behind participation in previous and potential future exercises are important; Russian and Chinese courtship of Iranian energy reserves and desires to independently appear as benevolent players amongst Eurasian states are potential explanations of their 'joint' participation in the previous exercises and may therefore not be useful indicators of why Russia and China might participate in bilateral exercises.  Conversely, this *broadens* the reasons why Russia and China might be tempted to participate in multilateral activities in areas of mutual benefit, though areas of mutual benefit that also facilitate naval exercises in particular limits the list a lot.  Arctic cooperation seems unlikely because of unease on both sides about monopoly, though @fueled_by_gummybears point on non-military exercises raises the overall chances of this event significantly.  This is because Russia-China non-military Arctic cooperation is subtle, relatively non-threatening, and “threads the needle” on several concerns I raise below.
Some factors that may make joint naval exercises less likely are related to Russia-China competition over energy (China as a consumer, Russia as producer), competition for primacy in the Arctic, Russian concerns over Chinese theft of technology (3), and especially over the dynamics of China as a rising great+ power and Russia as a struggling middle+ power. These may provide incentives on either side (especially the Russian) not to desire an exercise.  
China may see value in demonstrating closer cooperation with Russia, given hardening relationships with India and other regional powers.  From a realist perspective, Russia is incentivized to allow China to be counter-balanced by India and other local powers.  From an economic perspective, Russia may indeed be incentivized to cooperate with China to increase energy exports to China.  However, this is again mitigated by a Russia that is most likely concerned that China has many sources of energy and material from numerous middle eastern and African nations due to investment by general Chinese businesses, state-owned enterprises, and CCP-sponsored BRI initiatives.  In this situation, a savvy Russia might want China to be counterbalanced to create a longer-term balance against China that is of more value than a short-term increase in Russian exports.
Either China or Russia may see an opportunity to demonstrate concordance against a new US administration, which could be perceived as threatening by the United States without much concomitant gain for either Russia or China.  Threatening the US through this kind of action potentially supports a new US administration in forming domestic and/or international consensus' against Russia and/or China. It would have to be accompanied by some pretty important gains for Russia and China in return.  I could see an energy deal reaching this bar for Russia, but I also see it being at odds with China’s traditional strategy of appearing non-threatening. (4)  This entire line of thought is undermined because minor naval exercises, especially including non-military ones, are not all that big a deal. 
Neither Russia nor China have recently shown a desire to cooperate as peers with other great or near-great powers.. I find COVID-19 comments by @TheBlindMouse and @caj05 to be appealing, but I don't see Covid moving the chances by more than a few percentage points because if other factors in favor of this happening become convincing, I don't see Covid being the thing that overrides those factors.    
Overall, there are solid reasons for both the Russian and Chinese sides to either participate or not participate in a naval exercise in the near term.  From my ignorant perspective, the mitigating forces in either direction aren’t clear.  The overall rare nature of joint exercises, plus conservatism around a new US administration, plus forces running against cooperation in Russia and China, lead me to a qualified-negative forecast.

Russia and China's "comprehensive strategic partnership" continues to evolve. This relationship has had and will continue to have joint military exercises as a key foundation of engagement; however, they remain erratic. Additionally, the countries' overall level of satisfaction with the partnership may be waning. With this backdrop, it is important to note that military exercises remain ongoing, with the most recent occurring in September with Caucasus 2020, and seems to be the only major exercise in 2020 and was not primarily naval. However, 2019 saw two China-Russia engage in two primarily maritime exercises with one occurring in April and a second in late December. This second exercise was conducted with Iran in the Gulf of Oman and Indian Ocean and may provide some signal that it could reoccur this year as well. However, there are reasons to think that Russia and China (and Iran) will utilize the following four months as part of an information-gathering phase regarding US intentions. The recent US DOD shakeup and tense Presidential election make the US an arguably less predictable international actor until the beginning of the new presidential term. Compounding the issue is the possibility that Iran may attempt to strike back at the US in retaliation for the strike on Soleimani, and neither Russia nor China would likely want to be seen as supportive. They will likely remain concerning until well into its first 100 days. These factors: the mildly strained China-Russia relationship, Iranian tensions, and US unpredictability make a joint naval exercise in the near term unlikely.

According to the Diplomat.com, Russia and China participate in an annual joint navel exercise every year.  In 2019, it occurred between April 29 and May 4.  Presumably, this year's exercise would also occur during this time, after the cold winter conditions pass, and assuming there are no delays due to the COVID pandemic.  Therefore, it is likely that the preplanned joint exercise will occur during 2021, but after 1 March.  The only exception to this would likely be as a response to a geopolitical event that is difficult to predict.  For example, in 2019, Russia and China conducted a trilateral exercise with Iran in the northern Indian ocean in the last week of December, in response to US sanctions on Iran and joint US-Saudi military movements in response to RPA attacks on Saudi oil fields.  Therefore, the preplanned exercise will likely occur after 1 March, and the only likelihood of an exercise before this time would be in response to unpredictable geopolitical tensions, of which right now there are few specific indicators.

Russia and China have conducted joint naval exercises every year since 2012, these exercises occur in the summer months and not over the winter. However, they have also conducted trilateral exercises with Iran which have taken place in December. There have been no exercises conducted in 2020 so far. There have recently been joint land exercises involving Russia and China in Southern Russia, indicating that there is no diplomatic reason for the lack of naval exercises this year. Fleet availability could be a reason for the lack of exercises, as could the impact of COVID.  Now that vaccines are becoming more widely available and the historical precedent of winter naval exercises has been set, I consider a naval exercise more likely than not.

(Leaving this up for research purposes, but see above an exercise did occur in Dec 2019 that refutes the below) Russian and Chinese joint naval exercises have been increasingly frequent over the last decade and joint cooperation in anti-terrorist exercises has been extensive going back to the early 2000s. However, naval exercises must, almost certainly, involve one of three Russian formations: the Far-East/Pacific fleet in Vladivostok, the baltic fleet in Kaliningrad, or the Black Sea fleet in Sevastopol (ruling out the Russian Mediterranean Fleet in Syria due to the on-going war and the Russian North Sea Fleet due to the lack of surface vessels and extreme weather conditions in Murmansk). Two of these formations are in ports that are only semi-tenable from Nov to 1 Mar (Kaliningrad and Vladivostok) and the third in Sevastapol would require a Chinese fleet to transit to the Black Sea or the Black Sea Fleet to leave the Black Sea. Both of these propositions are very unlikely due to the distances involved, the requirement for Turkish acquiescence, and on-going disputes in Ukraine. Over the last decade, all but one of the ten joint Chinese-Russian exercises have involved the Chinese North or East Sea Fleets and the Russian Pacific Fleet. The harbor of Vladivostok is iced over during this period of most years. Additionally, no joint Russian-Chinese naval exercise has EVER occurred from 9 Nov to 1 Mar. Indeed no joint (land, air, or sea) exercise between China and Russia over the last 20 years has been held during 9 Nov - 1 Mar of more than 20 exercises. It is possible that such an event could occur, but it is HIGHLY improbable given the weather conditions, lack of historical evidence, and physical formations involved. 1% or perhaps 2% at best. Realistically the occurrence is probably closer to 0.3-0.5%, but, bereft of that option, I refuse to estimate something as a 0% likelihood of occurrence when it is feasible. (I concocted all of this from open-source information. I admit I could be incorrect about some of the details in terms of occurrences of exercises, rates, and formations participating in exercises, but the overall logical approach that joint Russian-Chinese naval exercises do not happen over winter still stands).
